1.0          INTRO
                 ODUCTIO
                       ON

         M
East Bay Municipal Utility District (E           p
                                     EBMUD) is a publicly-owne
                                                             ed utility form
                                                                           med under th
                                                                                      he Municipal Utility
District Act. EBMUD's water system
                                 m serves appr
                                             roximately 1. 3 million peo
                                                                       ople in a 325
                                                                                   5-square mile
                                                                                               e area
extending
        g from Crocke                                                 ward from San
                                             rd to Castro Valley, eastw
                    ett in the north, southwar                                    n Francisco B
                                                                                              Bay to
        reek, and south through th
Walnut Cr                        he San Ramon
                                            n Valley.

EBMUD is                         c
       s planning to replace the current     -cut style 39th
                                         open-             h
                                                             Avenue Rese
                                                                       ervoir in Oakl
                                                                                    land with a sm
                                                                                                 maller
tank type reservoir. Th
                      he replacemen                                      ubstantially im
                                                             ntended to su
                                  nt tank type reservoir is in                         mprove the d
                                                                                                  design
standards
        s and seismic stability of the facility.

This report evaluates transportation
                      t            n impacts related to cons
                                                           struction activ
                                                                         vities. Upon completion o
                                                                                                 of the
Project, trips to the reservoir site wo
                                      ould return to existing leve ls.

1.5          ANALY
                 YSIS METH
                         HODS

The operations of roa   adway facilities are descrribed with thhe term "leve  el of service"" (LOS). LOS S is a
          e description of traffic flow
qualitative                           w based on factors
                                                  f       such a
                                                               as speed, trav  vel time, dela
                                                                                            ay, and freedoom to
maneuver  r. Six levels of
                        o service are defined rangging from LOS S A (i.e., best operating coonditions) to LOS F
(worst opperating cond  ditions). LOSS E corresponnds to operat tions "at cap pacity." When volumes exceed
capacity, stop-and-go
          s              conditions result and oper
                                                  rations are de
                                                               esignated as L LOS F.

                       m
Different criteria and methods were            ess operating
                                  e used to asse           g conditions f
                                                                        for the various types of fac
                                                                                                   cilities
analyzed in this study,
                      , including sig
                                    gnalized and unsignalized
                                                            d intersections
                                                                          s, and roadw
                                                                                     way segments. The
         ria and metho
LOS criter           ods for each of
                                  o these facilities are descri bed in the fo llowing sectio
                                                                                           ons.

39th Avenue

                        placement Cons

         onditions at signalized intersections were

                                                                                             ection
         A
Capacity Analysis meth            ansportation Research Boa
                     hod of the Tra                       ard's 2000 Hi
                                                                      ighway Capac
                                                                                 city Manual (H
                                                                                              HCM).
This oper
        rations analys                                                  s (such as tra
                                                          characteristics
                     sis method uses various intersection c                          affic volumes
                                                                                                 s, lane
geometry
       y, and signal phasing)
                     p        to estimate
                                 e        the average
                                              a       contr

                                                                                                veling
through an
        a intersectio
                    on.                           porates delay associated w

1.5.2           UNSIGNA
                      ALIZED INT
                               TERSECTION
                                        NS

Traffic conditions at unsignalized in
                                    ntersections were
                                                 w    evaluate
                                                             ed using the HCM Unsign
                                                                                   nalized Interse
                                                                                                 ection
method from
       f    the 200
                  00 Highway Capacity
                             C        Man
                                        nual. With th
                                                    his method, operations a
                                                                           are defined b
                                                                                       by the
average control delay per vehicle (m
                                   measured in seconds)
                                               s        for e
                                                            each moveme
                                                                      ent that must
                                                                                  t yield the right-of-
way. For all-way stop-
                     -controlled int                         ontrol delay is calculated f
                                                 he average co
                                   tersections, th                                      for the interse
                                                                                                      ection
         e. This incorp
as a whole                                                ion, accelerat
                                               w decelerati
                      porates delay associated with                                 g and moving up in
                                                                       tion, stopping
the queue
        e. At two-way                                                       delay (and LO
                                  et-controlled intersections,, the control d
                    y or side stree                                                     OS) is calculate

1.5.3           ROADWA
                     AY SEGMEN
                             NTS

Roadway segments we
                  ere evaluated
                              d by comparing added Pro
                                                     oject volume
                                                                es to existing roadway seg
                                                                                         gment
volumes. An increase in traffic volu
                                   ume caused by
                                              b the Project
                                                          t of less than the typical d
                                                                                     daily fluctuatio
                                                                                                    ons in
          lume would be considere
traffic vol                                tible.
                                ed impercept                   Typica
                                                                    al daily fluctu
                                                                                  uations in traffic volume were
calculated
         d using three day traffic counts collected
                                                  d on each roa
                                                              adway segment.

1.6.2        CITY OF OAKLAND

         her Lead Agencies under CEQA,
Unlike oth                       C           s cities or cou
                                       such as             unty governm
                                                                      ments, EBMUD
                                                                                 D does not ha
                                                                                             ave its
own thres
        sholds or criteria for ident
                                   tifying signific
                                                  cant traffic im
                                                                mpacts. And, as stated in Government Code
Section 53
         3091 (d), "...Building ordina                          hall not apply
                                     ances of a county or city sh            y to the locati
                                                                                           ion or constru
                                                                                                        uction
of facilitie
           es for the pro                                                  mission of wat
                                    neration, storage, treatme nt, or transm
                        oduction, gen                                                   ter, wastewat
                                                                                                    ter, or
electrical energy by a local agency.
                                   ." Thus, unde
                                               er CEQA and the California
                                                                        a Governmen
                                                                                  nt Code, EBM
                                                                                             MUD is
not necessarily bound by local polic
                                   cies, standards, or significa nce criteria. N
                                                                               Nevertheless, it is the pract
                                                                                                           tice of
EBMUD to
       o work with host
                   h    jurisdicti
                                 ions and agencies during project plann
                                                                      ning so that their evaluati
                                                                                                ion of
potential impacts are consistent
                      c                                                   olicies to the e

                                                                                                      cable.
